# Discord Chat Analysis for ğŸ’»â”‚developers

## 1. Summary
The discussion primarily focused on technical aspects of Hyperfy, a web-based 3D platform built on Three.js. Key topics included avatar systems (VRM format), physics implementation, environment creation, and app development. Developers shared code snippets for raybeam creation, camera controls, and ocean effects. There was significant discussion about collision systems, with the Hyperfy Blender addon being highlighted as a solution for creating collision maps. The chat revealed ongoing development of several features including elemental apps, combat systems, and water physics. New users received guidance on the workflow: importing models into Hyperfy, using the build mode for scripting, and leveraging example code from the community. A debate occurred regarding runtime wearables for VRM avatars, with some advocating for a character customization approach that exports a single VRM rather than runtime equipment changes.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How are directions derived for raybeams? (asked by Saori) A: Directions are normalized Vector3, obtained by applying quaternion rotation to a forward vector (answered by Ashxn)
Q: How to persist state for an App to the sqlite database on the server? (asked by Cybernetic-O-Cult) A: Use world.get(key) and world.set(key, value) on the server side (answered by Saori)
Q: What's the best projectile .hyp available? (asked by MetaMike) A: The one in hyperworld.host with some improvements (answered by Shiffty)
Q: How do collisions work with custom .glb files? (asked by mooshu meezy) A: Use the Hyperfy Blender addon which handles collision setup (answered by Saori)
Q: Is there a way to play video in the scene? (asked by McCoder) A: Not yet officially supported (answered by MayD524)
Q: How to get the position the cursor is pointing at for raycast direction? (asked by mattimus) A: Saori shared code examples for this functionality (answered by Saori)

# Discord Chat Analysis for "âš¡â”‚general" Channel

## 1. Summary
The chat primarily revolves around Hyperfy, a web-based gaming/metaverse platform. Discussions indicate Hyperfy is approaching a significant platform launch that will open it up to non-developers. Currently, developers are building worlds in Hyperfy 2.0, with excitement about its mainstream potential. Ashxn shared that they're developing a high-risk PVP game internally to showcase the technology, attract creators, and provide entertainment. This game will require Hyper tokens to play and will feature weapon-based combat (swords, consumables) with rewards from kills going back to Hyper. The community also discussed development tools, with mentions of recraft.ai for SVG logo creation and questions about integrating various technologies. Regular tutorial sessions are being held, with the upcoming Episode 4 focusing on the .hyp app format, Hypkg (a mod manager), and App Rollup for external Hyp development.

The chat segment discusses a 3D model of arms/gloves shared via Twitter link. Community members critique the model's optimization, specifically focusing on file size (140kb) which they consider excessive. The discussion centers on two main optimization issues: triangle count and texture compression. Ashxn initially suggests the model has too many triangles, particularly in the sleeve ripples (estimated around 10k triangles). However, upon closer inspection with images shared by ğšŸğš˜ğš¡ğšŸğš’ğšğš—ğš—ğš, they note that the ripples are actually well-baked into the texture rather than being geometry-heavy. ğšŸğš˜ğš¡ğšŸğš’ğšğš—ğš—ğš points out that while the model uses 2K textures, the space isn't efficiently utilized, suggesting that the fingers and gloves could have been given double the resolution with better UV layout. The conversation acknowledges that for first-person shooter games where arms are prominently displayed close to the camera, higher detail might be justified, but still indicates the model could be significantly optimized.
